15.1.1 Signal mappings for Hybrid vehicles
Calculation of powertrain driver torque request:
(only combustion values)
TQ_DRIV_REQ_CUS = TQ_ENG_PTQ_REQ_FAST;
Calculation of scaled driver request including safety reactions:
(only combustion values)
If (TQ_ENG_MAX <= TQ_MIN_CLU)
then FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_CUS = 0
else FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_CUS = (TQ_ENG_PTQ_REQ_FAST-TQ_MIN_CLU)/
/(TQ_ENG_MAX- TQ_MIN_CLU);
endif
Calculation of scaled driver request from a torque request derived from gas pedal position without additional
limitatons/interventions
FAC_TQ_REQ_PV_CUS = FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV;
% currently no torque signal is available for this calculation, so it is
% treated equal to the FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV. Otherwise the above formula has to
% be used replacing TQ_DRIV_REQ by the appropriate torque value.

15.2.1.2.1.7 DRRQ_M904S/OPM__100MS/OPM/DYNAMIC_DETECTION_100MS/LOCK_OF_LIFT_1_DURING_TIP_
IN
If the vehicle is slow and Tip In�s are performed, the engine should stay in the current VVL position to prevent
unnecessary switches.
Depending on the VVL strategy 2 con?gurations are possible:
- VVL position is LIFT_1 while engine runs in Idle speed. For this setting, it?s necessary to avoid the switch to
STND position in case of the driver tip-in while drive train is open. Set LC_CONF_SWI_VVL_IS_STND==0
- VVL position is STND while engine runs in Idle speed. For this setting, it?s necessary to avoid the switch
to LIFT_1 position in case of the driver tip-in while drive train is open.

For this setting, it?s necessary to avoid the switch to
STND position in case of the driver tip-in while drive train is open. Set LC_CONF_SWI_VVL_IS_STND==0
- VVL position is STND while engine runs in Idle speed. For this setting, it?s necessary to avoid the switch
to LIFT_1 position in case of the driver tip-in while drive train is open. Set LC_CONF_SWI_VVL_IS_STND==1
Additionally, if the driver deactivates the ESP, the VVL switches are allowed even at tip-in events in order to
achieve the maximal engine dynamic.

Figure 15.3.4:
15.3.2.2 Drive request for hybrid vehicles
[#NC_PT_TYP == Hybrid]
In case of hybrid vehicles, the driver request is provided by a customer functionality. So the outputs are
mapped to customer variables.
In principle, FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV / TQ_DRIV_REQ, in an hybrid project, describe the driver torque factor / torque
requests to the Powertrain. This torque is realized by the combustion engine and/or the electrical machine. It
means that FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV does not have any relationship with the torque requested to the combustion
engine.
For compatibility reasons during the development phase, by setting LC_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_PT=0, it?s possible
to match FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV to the FAC_ENG_TQ_REQ_DRIV, so it describes the torque factor requested to
the combustion engine.
FAC_ENG_TQ_REQ_DRIV / TQ_ENG_DRIV_REQ describes the torque factor requested by the powertrain to the
combustion engine. It?s not directly related with the driver request
FAC_PT_TQ_REQ_DRIV /TQ_PT_DRIV_REQ describes the torque factor requested by the driver to the power-
train. It?s not directly related with the torque request to the combustion engine

15.3.2.3 Management of scaling factor for requested torque at clutch from driver
[#NC_CONF_TYP== Non hybrid]
The scaling factor FAC_TQ_REQ_PV is the interpretation of the torque wish of the driver depending on engine
speed and pedal value.
The management of scaling factor is divided up in
- scaling factor for low vehicle speeds and
- scaling factor for high vehicle speeds.
At low vehicle speeds the driver interpretation map IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_xxx is used and at high vehicle
speeds the map IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_xxx is used.

DRRQ, Pedal value interpretation
The weighing factor FAC_SLOP_DRIV between the two driver interpretation maps is set to zero at and below a
vehicle speed of C_VS_THD_MIN_MT/AT/CVT/DCT and is set to one at and above a vehicle speed of C_VS_THD_
MAX_MT/AT/CVT/DCT. Between the two thresholds the factor is linearly interpolated depending on the vehicle
speed.
For variants with 6 speed automatic transmission the driver interpretation maps are depending on the selectet
gear shift program.
The "sport program" is determined by LV_PV_SPT_ACT. When the sport mode is active, the calculated output is
multiplied by an additional factor (for MT) or the sport maps are selected (AT / CVT / DCT).
In case of manual transmission an detected driving off situation (LV_DROF = 1) the driver interpretation map
IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_DROF is used.
When the reverse gear is recognized (in case of manual transmission via detection of reverse- lamp switch, at
automatic transmission via selector lever position), the scaling factor is read from a separate map. This can be
deactivated by calibration for DCT and CVT variants.

15.3.2.3.5.1 Variants with AT (converter), CVT and DCT (NC_USE_AT = 1)
In case of NC_USE_AT = 1 (compiler switch to use the variant with CVT, DCT and 6- speed automatic transmis-
sion) the variable FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_PV is calculated depending on the state of the variable LV_CVT and LV_
DCT. In case of LV_CVT= 1 (CVT variant active) the block "CVT variant" is executed, otherwise it is checked whether
LV_DCT =1 (DCT_variant active) and executed. If both cases are not active the "AT variant" is triggered.

(LV_DROF = 1) the driver interpretation map IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_DROF is used.

15.3.2.3.6.2 Time based fading factor for drive-off
The weighing factor FAC_SLOP_DRIV_DROF weights the interpolation map for the driving off situation with the
standard maps. After driving off the factor is ramped down to zero.
SW hint: dT must always match function recurrence.

15.3.2.3.7 Coordination of driver request scaling factor
FAC_TQ_REQ_PV is limited by a calibratable value. So the driver request factor can be limited to 1. Normally
the driver requested factor should never override the value 1. It?s only allowed if an over-boost function is
implemented directly in the driver request calculation, and TQ_MAX_CLU is not increased to the values that
can be reached via over-boost.
The scaling factor from driver FAC_TQ_REQ_PV can be restricted in two cases:
a) PVS-brake torque limitation, if both the accelerator pedal and the brake pedal are applied simultaneously
b) PVS error, if an error of the pedal value sensor is detected
An active constraint is indicated by the boolean LV_INTV_PVS_LIH.
The restrictions are realized by two minimum selections. The result is the scaling factor FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV.

## Function

This Simulink diagram, titled "DRRQ Adaptive drive dynamics", represents a complex control system module designed to manage and adapt vehicle dynamic behavior. Its primary function is to process a wide array of vehicle operating conditions, driver requests, and internal states, performing calculations at different time scales (100ms and 1s) to generate control outputs. These outputs primarily influence variable valve lift (VVL) strategies and clutch control, ultimately impacting the vehicle's dynamic response and efficiency based on adaptive logic. The system likely coordinates various powertrain and chassis functions to achieve desired driving characteristics or to ensure optimal operation under changing conditions.

## Inputs

The system receives a large number of inputs, categorized as:

**1. System Control/Initialization:**
*   `DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_RST`: Main system reset signal.
*   `OPM_100MS_RST`: Reset for the 100ms operating mode.
*   `OPM_1S_RST`: Reset for the 1s operating mode.
*   `DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_100MS`: Primary input signal/data stream for the 100ms path.
*   `DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_1S`: Primary input signal/data stream for the 1s path.

**2. Vehicle State & Sensor Data (examples, as the list is extensive):**
*   `ACTION_FARM GetPermission Ts`
*   `CLV AMP`
*   `TR_VVL_SWI_TCJ` (Variable Valve Lift Switch)
*   `GEAR`
*   `IGA AD2 KNK`
*   `CLV AT2`, `CLV CH3`
*   `CLV CLU OPEN`, `CLV CLU SWI1`, `CLV CLU SWI 2` (Clutch status)
*   `CLV CRU ENA` (Cruise control enable)
*   `CLV CVT`, `CLV DCT` (Transmission type/status, e.g., Continuously Variable Transmission, Dual Clutch Transmission)
*   `CLV ESP SWI OFF CAN` (Electronic Stability Program switch status)
*   `CLV N GRD VLFT STND REQ` (Variable Valve Lift standard request)
*   `CLV N_MAX VST`
*   `CLV PUC`
*   `CLV PV SPT BCM ACT`, `CLV PV SPT TGU ACT`
*   `CLV REQ ISC`
*   `CLV TQI VLFT STND REQ WOUT DLY` (Torque VVL standard request without delay)
*   `CLV VS RUN` (Vehicle speed run)
*   `MAF SP TQI VVL GRD` (Mass Air Flow, specific torque, VVL gradient)
*   `N_1S`, `N_2S`, `N_3S`, `N_32`, `N_SP_IS` (Various speed or RPM signals)
*   `H_SP_IS_DROF_OEM`
*   `PV AV3`, `PV CLU`
*   `SEL PSN` (Selector position)
*   `STATE CRU 2`, `STATE CRU CTL` (Cruise control states)
*   `STATE VLFT MNG` (Variable Valve Lift management state)
*   `TCO` (Coolant temperature)
*   `TCQ S1`
*   `TIA`, `TOIL` (Temperatures, e.g., air, oil)
*   `TQI AV3`, `TQI MAXS`, `TQI REQ TRAS` (Various torque values/requests)
*   `TR ASTS`
*   `VSS` (Vehicle speed sensor)
*   `VS SP CRU` (Cruise control set speed)
*   `LV CAN ASR PAS TIP`
*   `LV_1S_F_REV_ACT_EOL`
*   `TQI_VVL_RFQ_MAN` (Torque VVL Request for Quote - Manual)
*   `CLV_VVL_LIM_` (Variable Valve Lift limit)

**3. Feedback Inputs:**
*   `[fc_OPM_100MS]`, `[feedback]` (for the 100ms path)
*   `[fc_OPM_1S]`, `[feedback]` (for the 1s path)
*   `[feedback]` (from the Signal Manager's output)

## Outputs

The system produces several crucial output signals, primarily related to variable valve lift and clutch control:

*   `output_100MS`: Output from the 100ms processing path.

*   `output_1S`: Output from the 1s processing path.
*   **From Signal Manager:**
    *   `<FAC_DYN_VVL_RED>`: Factor for dynamic VVL reduction.
    *   `<LV_DYN_VVL_RED_ACT>`: Level/status of dynamic VVL reduction activation.
    *   `<LV_DYN_VVL_RED_INH>`: Level/status of dynamic VVL reduction inhibition.
    *   `<LV_VLFT_STND_INH_EXT>`: Level/status of Variable Lift standard inhibition (external).
    *   `<LV_VVL_LFT1_INH_EXT>`: Level/status of Variable Valve Lift 1 inhibition (external).
    *   `<LV_VVL_STND_INH_11>`: Level/status of Variable Valve Lift standard inhibition 11.
    *   `<PV_CLU_GRD_USKP>`: Process value/status for clutch gradient upkeep (potentially related to slip control or engagement).

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of the DRRQ Adaptive Drive Dynamics system can be broken down into these steps:

1.  **System Initialization and Input Gathering:**
    *   The system begins with reset signals (`DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_RST`, `OPM_100MS_RST`, `OPM_1S_RST`) to ensure all internal states are properly initialized at startup or during specific events.
    *   A vast array of sensor data, vehicle states, and driver inputs (e.g., gear, speeds, temperatures, clutch status, torque requests, cruise control states) are continuously fed into the system from the left-hand side. These inputs represent the current operating context of the vehicle.

2.  **Rate-Scheduled Processing (OPM_100MS and OPM_1S):**
    *   The core logic is divided into two main processing blocks: `OPM_100MS` and `OPM_1S`. This division signifies different execution rates, where `OPM_100MS` processes time-critical or rapidly changing signals every 100 milliseconds, and `OPM_1S` handles slower-changing or less critical calculations every 1 second.
    *   Each OPM block receives its specific reset signal, relevant subsets of the global inputs, and dedicated feedback signals (`[fc_OPM_100MS]`, `[feedback]` for 100ms; `[fc_OPM_1S]`, `[feedback]` for 1s). The `DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_100MS` and `DRRQ_ISPCLADDRIDYN_1S` signals act as primary data streams or aggregated requests for these rate-dependent computations.
    *   These blocks perform their internal adaptive drive dynamics calculations, likely involving state estimation, control law execution, and decision-making based on the received inputs and feedback.
    *   They output `output_100MS` and `output_1S`, which represent the processed results for their respective rates.

3.  **Signal Aggregation and Management (Signal Manager):**
    *   The intermediate outputs `output_100MS` and `output_1S` are then channeled into a `Signal Manager` block (V.6.5). This block also receives several other direct inputs, such as `CLV_1S_F_REV_ACT_EOL`, `TQI_VVL_RFQ_MAN`, and `CLV_VVL_LIM_`.
    *   The `Signal Manager` is responsible for consolidating, prioritizing, limiting, or blending these various inputs and intermediate results. It ensures that the final control commands are consistent, safe, and adhere to overall system objectives. This might involve arbitration between different dynamic modes or applying operational constraints.
    *   It generates a `[feedback]` signal, suggesting that it might update internal states or provide information back to other parts of the system for continuous adaptation.

4.  **Final Output Generation:**
    *   Based on its comprehensive processing, the `Signal Manager` produces the final set of outputs. These outputs are primarily control commands or status flags related to Variable Valve Lift (VVL) and clutch management. Examples include signals for VVL reduction factors, activation/inhibition of VVL functions, and clutch-related gradient control. These signals are then sent to other vehicle control units (e.g., Engine Control Unit, Transmission Control Unit) to actively adjust the vehicle's dynamic behavior, such as engine power delivery and clutch engagement, according to the adaptive drive dynamics logic.

## Function
The primary function of this diagram is to determine the activation state of a "Variable Valve Lift (VVL) Switch/Solenoid Valve Lift (SVVL) Red 8" component, represented by the output signals `ILV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACTI` and `LV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACT`. This activation logic considers various system conditions, including inhibition flags, transmission types (CVT, DCT), Transmission Control Unit (TCU) activity, Body Control Module (BCM) activity, selector lever position, and a counter-based state. It is part of an "Adaptive drive dynamics" system.

## Inputs
*   **`CTR_VVL_SWI_SWI_RED_8`**: Current value of the VVL Red 8 counter/state.
*   **`CTR_VVL_SWI_SWI_RED_INC_8`**: Increment value for the VVL Red 8 counter.
*   **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_SWI_RED_MAX_8`**: Maximum threshold for the VVL Red 8 counter.
*   **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_SWI_RED_DEC_8`**: Decrement value for the VVL Red 8 counter.
*   **`ILV_VVL_SWI_SWI_RED_8_ACTI`**: Internal Logical Value for VVL Switch Red 8 Active (fed back from previous cycle or external source, also an output).
*   **`C_MOD_TRM_VVL_RED_INH_8`**: Module Termination VVL Red 8 Inhibition (a bit-packed word, from which individual bits (0-6) are extracted).
*   **`LV_PV_SPT_BCM_ACT`**: Powertrain VVL Switchpoint Body Control Module Active.
*   **`LV_CVT`**: Continuously Variable Transmission active/detected.
*   **`LV_PV_SPT_TCU_ACT`**: Powertrain VVL Switchpoint Transmission Control Unit Active.
*   **`SEL_PSN`**: Selector Position (e.g., Park, Reverse, Neutral, Drive; `14` likely refers to a specific state like Park/Neutral).
*   **`LV_GVTS`**: G-Vectoring Torque Split system active/detected (or potentially Gearbox/Vehicle Torque Split).
*   **`LV_DCT`**: Dual-Clutch Transmission active/detected.

## Outputs
*   **`ILV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACTI`**: Internal Logical Value for VVL Switch Red 8 Active. This is the main stateful output, incorporating counter logic.

*   **`LV_GVTS`**: G-Vectoring Torque Split system active/detected (or potentially Gearbox/Vehicle Torque Split).
*   **`LV_DCT`**: Dual-Clutch Transmission active/detected.

## Outputs
*   **`ILV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACTI`**: Internal Logical Value for VVL Switch Red 8 Active. This is the main stateful output, incorporating counter logic.
*   **`LV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACT`**: Logical Value for VVL Switch Red 8 Active. This is a direct activation signal based on real-time conditions.

## Logic Flow

The diagram calculates two main outputs: `LV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACT` (primary activation) and `ILV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACTI` (a stateful, combined activation).

**1. Calculation of `LV_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_8_ACT` (Primary Activation Signal):**
This signal is determined by a hierarchical structure of AND and OR gates, primarily on the right side of the diagram. It evaluates several groups of conditions, all of which must be met (connected by AND gates at higher levels) unless superseded by an OR condition. Each condition group checks if a specific inhibition bit (`GET BIT X of C_MOD_TRM_VVL_RED_INH_8`) is **not set** (i.e., `NOT` inhibition).

*   **Group 0 (Top-most right branch):**
    *   Checks if `GET BIT 0` of `C_MOD_TRM_VVL_RED_INH_8` is `false` (not inhibited).
    *   AND `LV_PV_SPT_BCM_ACT` is `true`.
    *   AND `LV_CVT` is `false` (`NOT LV_CVT`).
    *   The result of these three conditions being `true` feeds into the first main `AND` gate.

*   **Groups 1, 2, 3 (Middle-right branches):** These are combined with `OR` logic. At least one of these must be true:
    *   **Group 1:** `GET BIT 1` of `C_MOD_TRM_VVL_RED_INH_8` is `false` AND `LV_PV_SPT_TCU_ACT` is `true` AND `SEL_PSN` equals `14`.

## Function

This Simulink diagram, titled "DRRQ_M904S/OPM_1S/DYNAMIC_DETECTION_1S/AMP_DETECTION" (Figure 15.2.17), is designed to dynamically manage and adjust two distinct counters (`CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_TMP_5` and `CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_TMP_6`) based on specific "AMP conditions". Its primary role is to detect and react to certain amplitude (AMP) values, potentially representing an engine operating parameter, to influence adaptive drive dynamics. The system also filters a raw AMP signal and generates a reset flag (`CV_FIL_RST`) under specific deviation or threshold conditions. The overall purpose, as stated in the accompanying text, is to prevent "not necessary switches at i.e. low AMP" by allowing dynamic counters to increase under special AMP conditions.

## Inputs

The key inputs to this system are:

1.  **`CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_5` (prev value):** Feedback of the previous output for counter 5.
2.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_MAX_5`:** Maximum limit for counter 5.
3.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_INC_5`:** Increment value for counter 5.
4.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_DEC_5`:** Decrement value for counter 5.
5.  **`C_AMP_MIN_VVL_SWI_RED`:** A minimum AMP threshold used for comparison in counter logic.
6.  **`CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_6` (prev value):** Feedback of the previous output for counter 6.
7.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_MAX_6`:** Maximum limit for counter 6.
8.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_INC_6`:** Increment value for counter 6.
9.  **`C_CTR_VVL_SWI_VVL_RED_DEC_6`:** Decrement value for counter 6.
10. **`C_CRLC_AMP_VVL_SWI_RED`:** The raw AMP (amplitude) value.

## Function
This Simulink diagram image presents two interconnected subsystems primarily focused on signal conditioning and state preservation for parameters related to engine operation and driver torque requests within a "Pedal value interpretation" system (DRRQ).

Its primary function is twofold:
1.  **Filtering Engine Speed:** To smooth the raw engine speed signal ('N') using a first-order Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) filter, producing a filtered engine speed ('N_FIL_DRIV') for more stable control.
2.  **State Preservation:** To create delayed versions (representing values from the previous time step) of several key input signals, including the filtered engine speed and various driver torque request factors. These 'old' values are crucial for feedback loops, discrete-time calculations, and historical data access in subsequent control logic.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be described in two interconnected steps, corresponding to Figure 15.3.8 and Figure 15.3.7:

**Step 1: Engine Speed Filtering (Figure 15.3.8)**
1.  **Inputs Collection:** The raw engine speed `N`, a filter coefficient `C_FIL_N_DRIV`, and the previously calculated filtered engine speed `N_FIL_DRIV_old` (which is an output from Figure 15.3.7 from the previous time step) are fed into a custom or encapsulated IIR filter block (labeled 'm u x_in' with internal version V.7.5).
2.  **IIR Filter Calculation:** This block implements a first-order Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) filter. It uses the current raw engine speed `N` and the historical filtered engine speed `N_FIL_DRIV_old` (from the previous time step), along with the `C_FIL_N_DRIV` coefficient, to compute the current filtered engine speed `N_FIL_DRIV`. A common first-order IIR filter equation is `y[k] = (1-a)*x[k] + a*y[k-1]`, where `x[k]` is `N`, `y[k-1]` is `N_FIL_DRIV_old`, and `a` is a filter coefficient derived from `C_FIL_N_DRIV`.
3.  **Output Filtered Speed:** The calculated `N_FIL_DRIV` (current filtered engine speed) is output from this block. This signal is then available for subsequent control logic within the larger system, and crucially, it is also fed as an input to the delay mechanism shown in Figure 15.3.7.

**Step 2: Signal Delay and State Preservation (Figure 15.3.7)**
1.  **Inputs Collection:** A set of input signals, including the `N_FIL_DRIV` generated in Step 1, as well as various other driver torque request and slope factors (e.g., `<T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_out>`, `<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`, etc.), enter this block. The 'feedback' (Goto) and 'fb' (From) blocks indicate internal signal routing within a broader model context.
2.  **Unit Delay Application:** Each of these input signals is independently routed through a dedicated Unit Delay block (indicated by the triangular block with version V.6.4). A Unit Delay block stores its input value at the current simulation time step and outputs that *stored* value at the *next* simulation time step.
3.  **Output Delayed Values:** For each input signal `X`, a corresponding output signal `X_old` is generated. This `X_old` represents the value that `X` held in the immediately preceding discrete time step. For example, `N_FIL_DRIV` from the filter block (Step 1) becomes `N_FIL_DRIV_old` after passing through its respective Unit Delay block.

3.  **Output Delayed Values:** For each input signal `X`, a corresponding output signal `X_old` is generated. This `X_old` represents the value that `X` held in the immediately preceding discrete time step. For example, `N_FIL_DRIV` from the filter block (Step 1) becomes `N_FIL_DRIV_old` after passing through its respective Unit Delay block. This `N_FIL_DRIV_old` is then fed back into the IIR filter block (Figure 15.3.8) to be used in the calculation for the next time step, thus closing the filter's recursive loop.
4.  **Availability of Historical Data:** All other `_old` signals (e.g., `T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_old`, `FAC_TQ_REQ_PV_old`, etc.) are made available as outputs from this subsystem. These historical values are essential for control algorithms that require previous states or values for calculations like rate of change, integral terms, or adaptive control.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate a final **Fading Acknowledged Torque Requested Pedal Value (`<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`)** for a CVT-equipped vehicle. This calculation involves:
1.  Determining high and low requested torque values based on driver inputs, pedal availability, and operating modes (e.g., Sport, Nominal).
2.  Calculating a vehicle speed-based fading slope.
3.  Interpolating between the high and low torque requests using the calculated fading slope, effectively smoothing or adjusting the driver's torque request based on vehicle speed.

The lower diagram, "Vehicle speed based fading (CVT)", acts as a sub-function to calculate the fading slope used in the main diagram.

## Inputs

The key inputs to the overall system are:

*   **`<LV_TQ_REQ_DRIV_SPT>`**: Level Value Torque Requested Driver Sport (likely an x-axis value for look-up).
*   **`<N_FIL_DRIV>`**: Filtered Driver Input (e.g., filtered pedal position or normalized driver request for nominal mode, an x-axis value for look-up).
*   **`<N>`**: Nominal value (e.g., nominal engine speed or a generalized normalized input, an x-axis value for look-up).
*   **`<PV_AV_H>`**: Pedal Value Available High (likely a y-axis value for look-up, indicating high pedal availability or a certain operating range).
*   **`SPORT`**: A signal indicating Sport mode activation/status (y-axis value for look-up in Sport Low Torque calculation).

*   **`<N>`**: Nominal value (e.g., nominal engine speed or a generalized normalized input, an x-axis value for look-up).
*   **`<PV_AV_H>`**: Pedal Value Available High (likely a y-axis value for look-up, indicating high pedal availability or a certain operating range).
*   **`SPORT`**: A signal indicating Sport mode activation/status (y-axis value for look-up in Sport Low Torque calculation).
*   **`<VS>`**: Vehicle Speed (input for fading slope calculation).
*   **`C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT`**: Constant: Minimum Vehicle Speed Threshold for CVT fading.
*   **`C_VS_THD_MAX_CVT`**: Constant: Maximum Vehicle Speed Threshold for CVT fading.
*   **`phys_max`**: Physical maximum value (for the fading slope limiter).

## Outputs

The key outputs of the overall system are:

*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`**: Fading Acknowledged Torque Requested Pedal Value (the final calculated torque request).
*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS>`**: Fading Acknowledged Torque Requested Driver High (intermediate output for high torque path, vehicle speed dependent).
*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`**: Fading Acknowledged Torque Requested Driver Low (intermediate output for low torque path, vehicle speed dependent).
*   **`<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`**: Fading Slope Driver (calculated by the sub-function, used for interpolation).

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be divided into three main parts: calculating high/low torque requests, calculating the fading slope, and then combining them for the final torque request.

### Part 1: Calculation of High and Low Torque Requests

1.  **Sport High Torque Calculation**: A 2D look-up table (`IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_CVT`, V.7.7) takes `<LV_TQ_REQ_DRIV_SPT>` (x-axis) and `<PV_AV_H>` (y-axis) to determine a `Sport_H_TQ` value.
2.  **Nominal High Torque Calculation**: Another 2D look-up table (`IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_CVT`, V.7.7) takes `<N_FIL_DRIV>` (x-axis) and `<PV_AV_H>` (y-axis) to determine a `Nominal_H_TQ` value.
3.  **High Torque Request Selection**: A switch block (V.6.9, "Check == 0") selects between `Sport_H_TQ` and `Nominal_H_TQ`. If `Sport_H_TQ` is zero (acting as the control condition), `Nominal_H_TQ` is chosen; otherwise, `Sport_H_TQ` is chosen. The output is **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS>`**.
4.  **Sport Low Torque Calculation**: A 2D look-up table (`IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_CVT`, V.7.7) takes `<N>` (x-axis) and `SPORT` (y-axis) to determine a `Sport_L_TQ` value.
5.  **Nominal Low Torque Calculation**: Another 2D look-up table (`IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_CVT`, V.7.7) takes `<N>` (x-axis) and `<PV_AV_H>` (y-axis) to determine a `Nominal_L_TQ` value.
6.  **Low Torque Request Selection**: A similar switch block (V.6.9, "Check == 0") selects between `Sport_L_TQ` and `Nominal_L_TQ`. If `Sport_L_TQ` is zero, `Nominal_L_TQ` is chosen; otherwise, `Sport_L_TQ` is chosen. The output is **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`**.

### Part 2: Vehicle Speed Based Fading Slope Calculation (Sub-function `CLC_FAC_SLOP_DRIV_CVT`)

This block uses the lower diagram's logic:
1.  **Vehicle Speed Normalization**:
    *   The difference between current vehicle speed and minimum threshold (`<VS> - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT`) is calculated.
    *   The range of the thresholds (`C_VS_THD_MAX_CVT - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT`) is calculated.

**Vehicle Speed Normalization**:
    *   The difference between current vehicle speed and minimum threshold (`<VS> - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT`) is calculated.
    *   The range of the thresholds (`C_VS_THD_MAX_CVT - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT`) is calculated.
    *   The first result is divided by the second, normalizing the vehicle speed within the defined fading range: `norm_VS = (<VS> - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT) / (C_VS_THD_MAX_CVT - C_VS_THD_MIN_CVT)`.
2.  **Pre-Clamping**: The `norm_VS` is then limited (clamped) between `0` and `phys_max` using a min/max block (V.6.11).
3.  **Final Saturation**: The result is passed through a saturation block (V.6.17), which typically clamps the value between `0` and `1`. This output is **`<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`**.

### Part 3: Final Faded Torque Request Calculation

1.  **Torque Difference**: The difference between the high and low torque requests (`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS> - <FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`) is computed. This represents the total range of torque to be faded.
2.  **Apply Fading Slope**: This torque difference is multiplied by the calculated fading slope (`<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`).
3.  **Interpolation**: The result of the multiplication is then added to the low torque request (`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`). This performs a linear interpolation:
    `Output = <FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS> + (<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS> - <FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>) * <FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`.
4.  The final result is the **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`**.

## Function
This Simulink diagram's primary function is to calculate a **Factored Torque Request based on Pedal Value (`FAC_TQ_REQ_PV`)** for an automatic transmission (AT) vehicle with a torque converter. It achieves this by selecting between different drive modes (Off-Road, Sport, Normal) for both "High VS" (VS_H) and "Low VS" (VS_L) pedal characteristics, and then blending these two characteristics based on a vehicle speed-dependent fading factor. The selection and blending process adapts the pedal-to-torque mapping to the current driving conditions and desired vehicle behavior.

*   **`<N_FIL_DRIV>`**: Represents a filtered engine speed or gear ratio for driving, used as the X-axis input for Sport and Normal mode torque maps (e.g., `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_AT_S`, `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_AT`).

*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`**: The selected "Low VS" (low characteristic) factored torque request for the current drive mode.

*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS>`**: The selected "High VS" (high characteristic) factored torque request for the current drive mode.
*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`**: The selected "Low VS" (low characteristic) factored torque request for the current drive mode.
*   **`<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`**: The calculated fading factor (slope factor for drive mode) based on vehicle speed and other conditions, used for blending the high and low characteristics.
*   **`<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`**: The final, blended Factored Torque Request based on Pedal Value, representing the desired engine torque.

## Logic Flow

The diagram processes inputs in three main stages:
1.  **Mode-Dependent Torque Characteristic Selection:** This stage uses 2D lookup tables (maps) to determine torque requests based on engine speed/gear and pedal value, differentiating between Off-Road, Sport, and Normal modes for both "High VS" and "Low VS" characteristics.
2.  **Fading Factor Calculation:** A separate block calculates a blending factor based on gear and vehicle speed.
3.  **Blending and Final Torque Request Calculation:** The selected high and low torque characteristics are blended using the calculated fading factor to produce the final torque request.

Here's a step-by-step breakdown:

**1. Calculate High VS Torque Request (`FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS`):**
    *   **Off-Road High Torque:** The map `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_OFRD` (Off-Road, High characteristic) takes `<N>` (engine speed/gear) as the x-input and `<PV AV H>` (pedal value) as the y-input. Its output is fed to the top input of a 3-way switch.
    *   **Sport High Torque:** The map `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_AT_S` (AT Sport, High characteristic) takes `<N_FIL_DRIV>` and `<PV AV H>`. Its output is fed to the middle input of the switch.
    *   **Normal High Torque:** The map `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS_AT` (AT Normal, High characteristic) takes `<N_FIL_DRIV>` and `<PV AV H>`. Its output is fed to the bottom input of the switch.
    *   **Mode Selection (High):** A switch block (V.6.9) selects one of the three high torque map outputs. It prioritizes:
        *   Off-Road if `<LV_TQ_REQ_OFRD>` is active (e.g., `Check ~= 0`).
        *   Sport if `<LV_TQ_REQ_DRIV_SPT>` is active (e.g., `Check ~= 0`) and Off-Road is not active.
        *   Normal by default if neither Off-Road nor Sport are active.
    *   The output of this switch is `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS>`.

**2. Calculate Low VS Torque Request (`FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS`):**
    *   This section mirrors the "High VS" calculation, using analogous "Low VS" maps:
    *   **Off-Road Low Torque:** `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_OFRD` takes `<N>` and `<PV AV H>`.
    *   **Sport Low Torque:** `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_AT_S` takes `<N_FIL_DRIV>` and `<PV AV H>`.
    *   **Normal Low Torque:** `IP_FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS_AT` takes `<N_FIL_DRIV>` and `<PV AV H>`.
    *   **Mode Selection (Low):** An identical switch block (V.6.9) uses `<LV_TQ_REQ_OFRD>` and `<LV_TQ_REQ_DRIV_SPT>` to select the appropriate low torque map output, following the same prioritization logic as the high torque selection.
    *   The output of this switch is `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`.

**3. Calculate Fading Factor (`FAC_SLOP_DRIV`):**
    *   A custom block labeled "Vehicle speed based fading" (`CLC_FAC_SLOP_DRIV_AT`) takes `<GEAR>`, `<LV_TQ_REQ_OFRD>`, and `<VS_H_RES>` as inputs.

*   The output of this switch is `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`.

**3. Calculate Fading Factor (`FAC_SLOP_DRIV`):**
    *   A custom block labeled "Vehicle speed based fading" (`CLC_FAC_SLOP_DRIV_AT`) takes `<GEAR>`, `<LV_TQ_REQ_OFRD>`, and `<VS_H_RES>` as inputs.
    *   This block calculates a fading factor, `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`, which typically ranges between 0 and 1, indicating the blend ratio between the low and high characteristics.

**4. Blend and Determine Final Torque Request (`FAC_TQ_REQ_PV`):**
    *   **Difference Calculation:** A sum block (V.7.5) subtracts `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>` from `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS>` to find the difference between the high and low torque characteristics.
    *   **Scaling Difference:** A product block (V.7.6) multiplies this difference by `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>`. This scales the range between the low and high characteristics according to the fading factor.
    *   **Final Summation/Interpolation:** Another sum block (V.7.5) adds the scaled difference to `<FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS>`. This performs a linear interpolation:
        `FAC_TQ_REQ_PV = FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS + (FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS - FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS) * FAC_SLOP_DRIV`
        *   If `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>` is 0, `FAC_TQ_REQ_PV` equals `FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_L_VS`.
        *   If `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>` is 1, `FAC_TQ_REQ_PV` equals `FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV_H_VS`.
        *   Values of `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV>` between 0 and 1 result in a smooth blend.
    *   The result is the final output, `<FAC_TQ_REQ_PV>`.

## Diagram 1: Time based fading factor for drive-off (Figure 15.3.22)

### Function
This diagram calculates a time-based fading factor, `FAC_SLOP_DRIV_DROF`, which is used to smoothly ramp a weighting factor down to zero when a "drive-off" condition is active, and ramp it back up to one when the drive-off condition is inactive. This factor likely influences an interpolation map, smoothly adjusting system behavior during transitions.

### Inputs
*   `<LV_DROF>` (Boolean): A flag indicating whether the "drive-off" condition is currently active.
*   `C_T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF` (Numerical Calibration): A calibration constant representing the target maximum value of the internal ramp and used as the normalization factor.
*   `<T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_old>` (Numerical, Persistent State): The previous output value of the ramp, used for initialization or resetting the ramp block.

### Outputs
*   `<T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_out>` (Numerical): The raw, unnormalized output of the internal ramp generator.
*   `<FAC_SLOP_DRIV_DROF>` (Numerical): The final time-based fading factor, normalized to be between 0 and 1.

### Logic Flow
1.  **Drive-Off Condition Inversion:** The boolean input `<LV_DROF>` is fed into a `NOT` logical gate.
    *   If `<LV_DROF>` is TRUE (drive-off is active), the `NOT` gate output is FALSE.
    *   If `<LV_DROF>` is FALSE (drive-off is inactive), the `NOT` gate output is TRUE.
2.  **Ramp Generation (V.7.6):** The output of the `NOT` gate (inverted `<LV_DROF>`) controls the `E` (Enable) port of the `V.7.6` block (a specialized ramp generator or rate limiter).
    *   The `C_T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF` value is fed into both the `x_in` (target/rate input) and `IV` (initial value) ports of the ramp block.
    *   The `<T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_old>` value is fed into the `R` (Reset) port.
    *   Based on the function description ("factor is ramped down to zero after driving off"), the `V.7.6` block's behavior is interpreted as:
        *   When `NOT <LV_DROF>` is FALSE (i.e., `<LV_DROF>` is TRUE, drive-off active), the block ramps its output `x_out` downwards towards zero.

*   Based on the function description ("factor is ramped down to zero after driving off"), the `V.7.6` block's behavior is interpreted as:
        *   When `NOT <LV_DROF>` is FALSE (i.e., `<LV_DROF>` is TRUE, drive-off active), the block ramps its output `x_out` downwards towards zero.
        *   When `NOT <LV_DROF>` is TRUE (i.e., `<LV_DROF>` is FALSE, drive-off inactive), the block ramps its output `x_out` upwards towards `C_T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF`.
        *   The parameter `dT = 0.01` specifies the discrete time step for the ramp.
3.  **Unnormalized Ramp Output:** The raw output `x_out` from the `V.7.6` ramp block is directly assigned to the output `<T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF_out>`.
4.  **Fading Factor Calculation:** The `x_out` from the ramp block is divided by the calibration constant `C_T_RAMP_SLOP_DROF` using the `V.7.5` division block. This normalization produces the final fading factor `FAC_SLOP_DRIV_DROF`, which ranges from 0 to 1.

## Function
The primary function of this subsystem is to calculate a final, limited driver torque request (`TQ_DRIV_REQ`) specifically for the clutch. It takes a raw or factored driver torque request and maps it into an absolute torque value, ensuring it stays within the clutch's operational limits (minimum and maximum allowed torque). Essentially, it scales and offsets the driver's relative torque demand based on the current clutch torque capabilities.

## Inputs
*   **`FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV`**: (Factor/Scaled Driver Torque Request) This input represents the driver's torque request, likely as a normalized value (e.g., 0-1) or a factor that indicates the desired proportion of available torque.
*   **`TQ_MAX_CLU`**: (Maximum Clutch Torque) This input specifies the maximum torque the clutch can currently transmit or is allowed to transmit. It acts as an upper limit.
*   **`TQ_MIN_CLU`**: (Minimum Clutch Torque) This input specifies the minimum torque the clutch can currently transmit or is allowed to transmit. It acts as a lower limit.

## Outputs
*   **`TQ_DRIV_REQ`**: (Driver Torque Request) This is the calculated absolute torque value that represents the driver's request, constrained and scaled according to the clutch's operational limits.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be broken down into the following steps:

1.  **Positive Driver Request Component (max block):**
    *   The `FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV` signal (driver's raw/factored torque request) enters a `max` block.
    *   The `max` block compares `FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV` with a constant value of `0`.
    *   The output of this block is `max(FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV, 0)`. This ensures that any negative driver request component is truncated to zero, preventing a request for torque below the minimum clutch limit from being generated by this component. Let's call this intermediate signal `PositiveDriverReqFactor`.

2.  **Calculate Clutch Torque Span (sum block with '+ -'):**
    *   The `TQ_MAX_CLU` (maximum clutch torque) and `TQ_MIN_CLU` (minimum clutch torque) signals are fed into a sum block.
    *   `TQ_MAX_CLU` is added (`+`), and `TQ_MIN_CLU` is subtracted (`-`).
    *   The output of this block is `TQ_MAX_CLU - TQ_MIN_CLU`. This represents the available operational torque range or span for the clutch. Let's call this `ClutchTorqueSpan`.

3.  **Scale Driver Request (product block 'X'):**
    *   The `PositiveDriverReqFactor` (from step 1) and the `ClutchTorqueSpan` (from step 2) are fed into a product block ('X').
    *   The output of this block is `PositiveDriverReqFactor * ClutchTorqueSpan`. This scales the driver's (positive) request factor by the available clutch torque range. If `PositiveDriverReqFactor` is, for example, 0.5, it means the driver is requesting half of the available torque span. Let's call this `ScaledDriverOffset`.

4.  **Apply Minimum Torque Offset and Final Result (sum block with '+ +'):**
    *   The `ScaledDriverOffset` (from step 3) and the `TQ_MIN_CLU` (minimum clutch torque) are fed into a final sum block, both with positive (`+`) signs.
    *   The output of this block is `ScaledDriverOffset + TQ_MIN_CLU`.

Let's call this `ScaledDriverOffset`.

4.  **Apply Minimum Torque Offset and Final Result (sum block with '+ +'):**
    *   The `ScaledDriverOffset` (from step 3) and the `TQ_MIN_CLU` (minimum clutch torque) are fed into a final sum block, both with positive (`+`) signs.
    *   The output of this block is `ScaledDriverOffset + TQ_MIN_CLU`.
    *   This addition offsets the scaled request by the minimum allowed clutch torque, yielding the final `TQ_DRIV_REQ`. This means if `PositiveDriverReqFactor` was 0, the output `TQ_DRIV_REQ` would be `TQ_MIN_CLU`. If `PositiveDriverReqFactor` were 1 (assuming it can go up to 1), the output would be `TQ_MAX_CLU`.

In summary, the subsystem takes a driver's relative or normalized request (`FAC_TQ_REQ_DRIV`), ensures it's positive, then scales it to fit within the `TQ_MIN_CLU` to `TQ_MAX_CLU` range, providing a final absolute torque demand `TQ_DRIV_REQ` to be applied to the clutch.

## Logic Flow

## Function
The primary function of this diagram, as indicated by its title "Aktivierungsbedingungen fuer Momentenlimitierung" (Activation conditions for torque limitation), is to determine the conditions under which an automotive torque limitation system should be activated. It evaluates various sensor inputs, system states, and permissions to output a final activation signal for torque limiting.

## Inputs
Here are the key input signals to the system:

*   **`PV_AVS`**: Pedal Value Available/Active Status (likely related to accelerator pedal sensor).
*   **`LV_BLS`**: Brake Light Switch status (logical, indicating brake pedal pressed).
*   **`LV_BTS`**: Brake Test Switch status (likely for system diagnostics or specific test modes).
*   **`C_T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK`**: Constant/Threshold value for the PVS/BLS/BTS check timer.
*   **`FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_LIM`**: Factor for maximum torque limit based on PVS/BLS.

*   **`LV_BTS`**: Brake Test Switch status (likely for system diagnostics or specific test modes).
*   **`C_T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK`**: Constant/Threshold value for the PVS/BLS/BTS check timer.
*   **`FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_LIM`**: Factor for maximum torque limit based on PVS/BLS.
*   **`FAC_TQ_REQ_PV`**: Factor for torque requested based on pedal value.
*   **`PRS_BRAKE_CAN`**: Brake pressure or status signal received via CAN bus.
*   **`C_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_THD`**: Constant/Threshold for the CAN brake pressure/status.
*   **`C_VS_FILL`**: Constant/signal related to vehicle speed or a fill level.
*   **`C_VS_PVS_BLS_TQ_LIM`**: Constant/Threshold for vehicle speed related to PVS/BLS torque limit.
*   **`PRM_FID_ACTION_FAR_GetPermission`**: Permission request ID for an action (e.g., from a functional safety monitor).

*   **`C_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_MAX`**: Maximum threshold for the CAN brake signal.
*   **`LV_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_NOT_VLD`**: Logical flag indicating the CAN brake signal is not valid.
*   **`LV_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_DIR`**: Logical flag indicating a "direct" or specific CAN brake signal status.

## Outputs
Here are the key output signals produced by the system:

*   **`LV_PVS_BLS_CHK_ENA_TMP`**: Temporary enable signal for PVS/BLS check (also used as feedback).
*   **`T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK`**: Output indicating that the PVS/BLS/BTS check timer has elapsed.
*   **`LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TQ_LIM`**: Activation signal for PVS/BLS/BTS torque limitation.
*   **`LV_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK_TMP`**: Temporary combined check signal for PVS/BLS/BTS.
*   **`LV_PVS_BLS_TQ_LIM`**: The final activation signal for the PVS/BLS-based torque limitation.

## Logic Flow

The logic flow can be broken down into several interconnected stages:

1.  **Initial PVS/BLS Check Enable (`LV_PVS_BLS_CHK_ENA_TMP`)**:
    *   The system first checks if `PV_AVS` (Pedal Value) is exactly `0` (meaning the accelerator pedal is not pressed).
    *   Simultaneously, it checks if neither the Brake Light Switch (`LV_BLS`) nor a Brake Test Switch (`LV_BTS`) is active (`NOT(LV_BLS OR LV_BTS)`).
    *   If both conditions are true (`(PV_AVS == 0) AND NOT(LV_BLS OR LV_BTS)`), it sets an SR Flip-Flop.
    *   The output `Q` of this Flip-Flop, `LV_PVS_BLS_CHK_ENA_TMP`, becomes TRUE, latching this "pedal not pressed, brakes not active" state. This signal can be reset by its own previous state, indicating a mechanism to clear the temporary enable.

2.  **PVS/BLS/BTS Check Timing (`T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK`)**:
    *   If `LV_PVS_BLS_CHK_ENA_TMP` is active AND `PV_AVS` is still `0`, an integrator/accumulator (`M_xout`) starts counting. It integrates a value of `1` every `0.04` seconds.
    *   This accumulator's output (`x_out`) is then compared against a threshold `C_T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK`.
    *   If `x_out` is greater than or equal to this threshold AND `LV_PVS_BLS_CHK_ENA_TMP` is still active, the output `T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK` becomes TRUE. This indicates that the "pedal not pressed, brakes not active" condition has persisted for a sufficient duration.

3.  **PVS/BLS/BTS Torque Limit Activation (`LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TQ_LIM`)**:
    *   This output becomes TRUE if either of two conditions is met:
        *   The maximum allowed torque limit (`FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_LIM`) is less than the currently requested torque by the pedal (`FAC_TQ_REQ_PV`).

3.  **PVS/BLS/BTS Torque Limit Activation (`LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TQ_LIM`)**:
    *   This output becomes TRUE if either of two conditions is met:
        *   The maximum allowed torque limit (`FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_LIM`) is less than the currently requested torque by the pedal (`FAC_TQ_REQ_PV`). This suggests a situation where the driver's request exceeds a predefined safe limit.
        *   OR the `T_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK` signal (from step 2) is TRUE, indicating the timed "pedal/brake inconsistency" has been detected.

4.  **Combined PVS/BLS/BTS Check (`LV_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK_TMP`)**:
    *   This section combines `LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TQ_LIM` with further brake and speed-related conditions:
        *   It checks if `PRS_BRAKE_CAN` (CAN brake status) is greater than or equal to a threshold `C_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_THD`, AND if `LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TQ_LIM` is active.
        *   Separately, it checks if `PV_AVS` is greater than `0` (pedal is pressed) AND `C_VS_FILL` is less than `C_VS_PVS_BLS_TQ_LIM` (vehicle speed related condition).
    *   All these four conditions must be true (via two nested `AND` gates) for `LV_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK_TMP` to become TRUE. This means the system detects both torque limit activation (due to requested vs. max torque or timed inconsistency) AND specific brake/pedal/speed states.

5.  **Final PVS/BLS Torque Limit Activation (`LV_PVS_BLS_TQ_LIM`)**:
    *   This is the ultimate output for activating torque limitation. It requires three main conditions to be simultaneously true:
        *   **Permission Granted (`PRM_LV_PRMS`)**: A permission status obtained from an `ActionImport` block, using `PRM_FID_ACTION_FAR_GetPermission` and `NC_FID_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK_CAN`. This likely acts as a safety or operational interlock.
        *   **Combined Check Active (`LV_PVS_BLS_BTS_CHK_TMP`)**: The result from step 4 must be true.
        *   **Valid Brake CAN Status**: This is determined by three sub-conditions logically ANDed:
            *   `PRS_BRAKE_CAN` is NOT equal to `C_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_MAX`.
            *   `LV_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_NOT_VLD` is FALSE (meaning the CAN brake signal is valid).
            *   `LV_PRS_BRAKE_CAN_DIR` is FALSE (meaning a specific direct brake status is not active).

In summary, the system activates torque limitation when specific system permissions are granted, a complex combination of pedal, brake (both switch and CAN), and vehicle speed conditions are met, AND a robust check on the CAN brake signal confirms its validity and status. The logic incorporates a timed check for potential pedal/brake inconsistencies, a common feature in automotive safety systems.

## Function
This Simulink diagram implements a torque limiting strategy. Its primary function is to calculate and output the maximum permissible engine torque (`FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_BTS_LIM`) based on various inputs related to driver demand (pedal value) and vehicle operating conditions (e.g., brake switch states). It uses a conditional logic to apply different limiting rules depending on whether a specific active limit condition is present.

## Inputs
*   **<LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TO_LIM>**: A boolean (true/false) flag that acts as the condition for the main `if-else` block. It indicates if a torque limit is actively being imposed due to the Pedal Value Switch (PVS), Brake Light Switch (BLS), or Brake Test Switch (BTS).
*   **-PV_val**: An analog signal representing the driver's accelerator pedal position or requested torque value.
*   **<TQ_MIN_CLU>**: A minimum torque value, likely related to clutch operation or a minimum allowable engine torque.

It indicates if a torque limit is actively being imposed due to the Pedal Value Switch (PVS), Brake Light Switch (BLS), or Brake Test Switch (BTS).
*   **-PV_val**: An analog signal representing the driver's accelerator pedal position or requested torque value.
*   **<TQ_MIN_CLU>**: A minimum torque value, likely related to clutch operation or a minimum allowable engine torque. It appears multiple times, suggesting it's used as a lower bound or adjustment factor in different calculations.
*   **resolution**: A numerical value used as an adjustment or scaling factor within the limit calculation logic.
*   **phys_max**: The absolute physical maximum torque that the system or engine can potentially produce or is allowed to produce under normal circumstances.

## Outputs
*   **FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_BTS_LIM**: The final calculated maximum permissible engine torque. This value is used by other parts of the system to cap the actual engine torque output.

## Logic Flow

The diagram's logic flows based on a conditional check that determines which set of calculations to apply for torque limiting:

1.  **Evaluate Active Limit Condition**: The system starts by evaluating the boolean input `<LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TO_LIM>`. This signal serves as the condition (`cond_if`) for the central `if-else` block (labeled `V.6.3`).

2.  **Path 1: Limit Active (If `cond_if` is TRUE)**:
    *   If `<LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TO_LIM>` is true (indicating an active limit from pedal or brake switches), the logic follows the "if" branch.
    *   The `-PV_val` (pedal value) is fed into a 1-D Lookup Table (`IP_TQ_MAX_PVS_LIM V.7.7`). This table converts the pedal input into a preliminary maximum torque value.
    *   The output of this lookup table passes through a block labeled `V.7.5` (likely a pass-through or a simple gain block).
    *   This processed value then becomes the output for the "if" branch of the `if-else` block.

3.  **Path 2: Limit Not Active (Else `cond_if` is FALSE)**:
    *   If `<LV_ACT_PVS_BLS_BTS_TO_LIM>` is false (no active limit from pedal or brake switches), the logic follows the "else" branch.
    *   In this branch, a maximum torque limit is derived primarily from `phys_max` and `TQ_MIN_CLU`.
    *   Specifically, `phys_max` is the first input to a subtraction block.
    *   The value subtracted from `phys_max` is the output of a `max` block (labeled `V.6.10`). This `max` block compares several inputs: one value derived from `TQ_MIN_CLU` (potentially adjusted by a preceding `+` block) and another value involving `resolution` (also potentially adjusted by another `TQ_MIN_CLU` via a `+` block). This sub-path effectively calculates a dynamic minimum value.
    *   The result of `phys_max - (calculated_dynamic_minimum)` then passes through a block labeled `V.6.3` (likely a pass-through or a simple gain block).
    *   This processed value becomes the output for the "else" branch of the `if-else` block.

4.  **Merge and Output**:
    *   The outputs from both the "if" branch (when the limit is active) and the "else" branch (when the limit is not active) are fed into a `Merge` block.
    *   The `Merge` block selects the appropriate torque limit value based on which branch was executed by the `if-else` condition.
    *   The final output of the `Merge` block is `FAC_TQ_MAX_PVS_BLS_BTS_LIM`, representing the effective maximum permissible engine torque for the current operating conditions.

## Diagram 1: 15.4.2.2.1 SAS aktiv

### Function
This subsystem calculates a "Limp Home" engine speed setpoint (`<N_SP_IS_LIH>`) and an associated boolean flag (`<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>`) when the Safety and Assistance System (SAS) is considered active. It dynamically selects between different maximum engine speed limits based on a request for a monitored limit, applies a fixed offset, and then imposes a final hard limit.

### Inputs
*   `<LV_N_LIM_REQ_MON>` (Boolean): A flag indicating if a monitored engine speed limit request is active for Limp Home.
*   `<EN_MAX_ETC_LIH>` (Numerical): Maximum engine speed limit for Limp Home as provided by the Electronic Throttle Control (ETC) system.
*   `<EN_MAX_MTC_LIH>` (Numerical): Maximum engine speed limit for Limp Home as provided by the Manual Throttle Control (MTC) system.
*   `<C_N_MAX_MON>` (Numerical): A constant representing a maximum engine speed for monitoring purposes.
*   `C_N_SP_IS_LIH_DIF` (Numerical): A constant engine speed difference value (e.g., 1504 rpm) to be added to the base limit.
*   `NC_N_SP_IS_LIH_LIM` (Numerical): A numerical constant representing a hard upper limit for the final Limp Home engine speed.

### Outputs
*   `<N_SP_IS_LIH>` (Numerical): The calculated Limp Home engine speed setpoint in rpm.
*   `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` (Boolean): A flag indicating whether the Limp Home engine speed setpoint is active or valid, directly mirroring the monitoring request.

### Logic Flow
1.  **Conditional Selection of Base Maximum Speed:** An `If` block (`cond_if`, V.6.3) evaluates the input `<LV_N_LIM_REQ_MON>`.
    *   **If `<LV_N_LIM_REQ_MON>` is true (If branch):** The system calculates the minimum of three values: `<EN_MAX_ETC_LIH>`, `<EN_MAX_MTC_LIH>`, and `<C_N_MAX_MON>`. This results in a potentially more restrictive limit when monitoring is active.
    *   **If `<LV_N_LIM_REQ_MON>` is false (Else branch):** The system calculates the minimum of only two values: `<EN_MAX_ETC_LIH>` and `<EN_MAX_MTC_LIH>`.
2.  **Merging and Offset Application:** The selected minimum value from either the `if` or `else` branch is fed into a `Merge` block, producing an intermediate value `n_max_lih_tmp`. This value is then increased by the constant `C_N_SP_IS_LIH_DIF`.
3.  **Final Speed Limit Determination:** The result from step 2 is then limited by `NC_N_SP_IS_LIH_LIM` using a `min` block. The smaller of these two values becomes the final Limp Home engine speed setpoint, `<N_SP_IS_LIH>`.
4.  **Limp Home Speed Flag Output:** The boolean output `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` is directly determined by the `If` block's condition. If `<LV_N_LIM_REQ_MON>` is true, the `if` branch's constant `1` (true) is propagated, otherwise, an implied `0` (false) from the `else` branch.

## Diagram 2: 15.4.2.2.2 SAS nicht aktiv

### Function
This subsystem manages the overall Limp Home (LIH) state and computes or updates various Limp Home related engine speed values (`<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>`, `<N_SP_IS_LIH>`, `<N_SP_IS_LIH_TMP>`, `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>`) when the Safety and Assistance System (SAS) is inactive. It determines whether the LIH state should be active based on vehicle occupation and system permissions, and then executes either an "active" or "passive" LIH calculation strategy.

### Inputs
*   `<LV_OCC_IS_H_ACT>` (Boolean): Status indicating if high-level vehicle occupation is active.

It determines whether the LIH state should be active based on vehicle occupation and system permissions, and then executes either an "active" or "passive" LIH calculation strategy.

### Inputs
*   `<LV_OCC_IS_H_ACT>` (Boolean): Status indicating if high-level vehicle occupation is active.
*   `<LC_PVS_OCC_ENA>` (Boolean): Enable flag for Pedal Value Sensor (PVS) occupation logic.
*   `<ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3>` (x2) (Boolean): Outputs from a "Fault Acknowledge and Recovery Management" (FARM) system, requesting specific permissions (type T3).
*   `NC_FID_N_SP_IS_LIH_1_ENA` (Boolean): Enable flag for the first Limp Home speed permission path.
*   `NC_FID_N_SP_IS_LIH_2_ENA` (Boolean): Enable flag for the second Limp Home speed permission path.
*   `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` (Boolean): An external flag indicating the Limp Home state's activation, which controls the lower conditional logic. (Note: This input has the same name as an output calculated in the top section of this diagram, suggesting potential feedback or coordination with other parts of the system.)
*   `<LV_BLS>` (Boolean): Status of the Brake Light Switch.
*   `<LV_BTS>` (Boolean): Status of the Brake Test Switch.
*   `<VS>` (Numerical): Current vehicle speed.
*   `<N>` (Numerical): Current engine speed.
*   `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>` (Numerical): A memorized or stored Limp Home engine speed value, used as an input to the active LIH calculation.
*   `NC_N_SP_IS_LIH_LIM` (Numerical): A numerical constant representing a hard limit for Limp Home engine speed.
*   `N_SP_IS_LIM` (Numerical): Another numerical constant representing a general Limp Home engine speed limit.

### Outputs
*   `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` (Boolean): The internally calculated primary flag indicating if the Limp Home state should be active (determined by the top section).
*   `<N_SP_IS_LIH>` (Numerical): The calculated Limp Home engine speed setpoint.
*   `<N_SP_IS_LIH_TMP>` (Numerical): A temporary Limp Home engine speed value.
*   `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>` (Numerical): The updated or determined memorized Limp Home engine speed value.

### Logic Flow
1.  **Primary Limp Home Active Flag Determination (Top Section):**
    *   An `AND` block checks if both `<LV_OCC_IS_H_ACT>` and `<LC_PVS_OCC_ENA>` are true.
    *   A `cond_if` block (V.6.3) uses the output of the `AND` block as its condition:
        *   **If true (high occupation active):** A constant `1` (true) is passed as a candidate for the `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` output.
        *   **If false (high occupation inactive):**
            *   Two separate paths involve `ActionImport` blocks processing `ACTION_FARM_GetPermission_T3` based on whether `NC_FID_N_SP_IS_LIH_1_ENA` or `NC_FID_N_SP_IS_LIH_2_ENA` are active. Each `ActionImport` outputs `PRM_LV_PRMS`.
            *   These two `PRM_LV_PRMS` values are combined by an `OR` block.
            *   The result of the `OR` block is then negated by a `NOT` block.
    *   A `Merge` block (V.6.4) combines the output from the `if` branch (constant `1`) and the negated `OR` result from the `else` branch to produce the final output `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>`. This means LIH is active if high occupation is detected, or if no specific FARM permissions for LIH are granted.

2.  **Limp Home Speed Value Calculation (Bottom Section):**
    *   A second `cond_if` block (V.6.3) uses the *input* `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` (the inward-pointing signal) to determine the operating mode:
        *   **If input `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` is true (Limp Home Active path):**
            *   The subsystem `CLC_N_SP_LIH_ACTIVE` (LIH Active, X.2.2.2.1) is executed.

*   It receives inputs: `<LV_BLS>`, `<LV_BTS>`, `<VS>`, `<N>`, and the stored `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>`.
            *   It outputs `<N_SP_IS_LIH>` and `<N_SP_IS_LIH_TMP>`, which become the overall outputs for these signals.
        *   **If input `<LV_N_SP_IS_LIH>` is false (Limp Home Inactive path):**
            *   A `min` block calculates the minimum of `NC_N_SP_IS_LIH_LIM` and `N_SP_IS_LIM`.
            *   This minimum value is passed to the subsystem `CLC_N_SP_LIH_PASSIVE` (LIH inactive, X.2.2.2.2).
            *   The `LIH inactive` subsystem outputs `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>`.
    *   A `Merge` block (V.6.3) specifically handles the `<N_SP_IS_LIH_MEM>` signal, receiving its input *only* from the `CLC_N_SP_LIH_PASSIVE` subsystem. This implies that the memorized speed is updated when LIH is passive, and the previously stored value is used as an input when LIH is active.
